comments.commentBody: Rubio did great tonight; however, he does not come across as a leader.  Nobody can picture him as president.  He might pick up a few votes on Super Tuesday, but those votes will likely be from the "undecideds", not from Trump's support which is pretty solidified at this point.

Rubio is the con artist.
Can Rubio name ONE accomplishment in the US Senate or in his personal life??

The Republican "debates" are a "bad boy" reality show in which "winning" or "doing great" has nothing to do with leadership, policy or any aspect of governance.  Full of sound and fury signifying nothing.
He came off looking desperate and RNC "sound bitey".
This is really what passes as a debate?
And THIS is our politics, our pool of statesmen. Heaven help us.

I see the spin in the mainstream media is to claim Rubio was effective in attacking Trump. I thought he came off like a small barking dog. I am no fan of any of the Republicans, but it was obvious that Trump still held the power onstage. Cruz and Rubio are small fry. Kasich seems sane and reasonable, still. Very likable. I never really understand what Carson is talking about (his health care plan based on familial surveillance and guilt trips was nuts! "Hey grandpa, stop smoking! We need to save money in our healthcare savings plan!").
Rubio seemed like a small yapping dog to me, too.
I wouldn't want to have a beer with kasich, it is tea party through and through with lipstick on
I thought the whole thing was an embarrassment.  Like three five-year olds  trying to out shout each other to draw attention to themselves.

One issue that should be debated: Would the Presidential candidates rule out imposing a draft if the war in Iraq escalates? If the answer is no, would the military draft apply to men and women? And- if the Presidential candidate avoided military service in the past, would he favor providing americans who don't want to fight the chance to do community service in lieu of military service?

I fear that if Donald Trump, Ted Cruz or Marco Rubio are elected that a draft could be reinstated. PAUL FEINER, Greenburgh, NY

A draft for military service and/or national service is a good idea.   The current military is in many ways a 'jobs' program.   A draft entails political costs that help prevent endless series of undeclared wars.

Granted, it's been a while, but there have been some fine Republican presidents. Two that come immediately to mind are Abraham Lincoln, arguably our best, and Dwight David Eisenhower, a man who served this nation long and well.

What would either of them have thought about this evening's GOP pig circus?
The thing is, in the time of Abraham Lincoln being a republican would mean being a democrat today
Theodore Roosevelt was a Republican, too, believe it or not.
Mamie would have had another drink and Ike would put a ball.
No presidential material here, not even close. If any of these clowns are the best person that we can put in the White House, than America is toast. Either Sanders or Clinton would be far better.
to put it quite mildly

The purpose of the clown car and these debates is to distract us from the important issues.

There are two important issues. They are inheritance and redistricting. Until inherited fortunes are outlawed we will have people like the Koch brothers, who inherited several billion dollars each, subverting democracy with cash. Until redistricting is done the way the Founders intended we will have a Republican congress in a country with a Democratic majority in almost every state.

What to do? Go to YouTube watch Comedy Party Platform and Benton-Comedy2, each under 3 minutes. It's not rocket science but it takes understanding and courage. Then help level the playing field by sending a buck to Bernie Sanders, and invite me to speak. Thanks! Good luck, America!
Inherited fortunes outlawed!  If someone works to amass a fortune, so you think they should be forced to turn it over to the state at gunpoint?  Maybe in Bernie Sanders' America.  Incredible.

Dave, thanks for your reply. In some other societies, the possessions of the very rich are burned upon death, not turned over to the state. This is specifically to prevent the heirs, who did NOT earn the wealth, from gaining undemocratic political power.

Details and discussion are in a recent book from Harvard University Press, called The Origins of Inequality. Check my Comedy Party Platform on YouTube for a summary of what should be done (2 min 9 sec).

The only persons on the stage that made any sense were Kasich and Carson. However, although they didn't get involved in the bar room brawl, Carson seemed to be on another planet and all Kasich could say is that he has done everything and it was a roaring success. Ohio must be the greatest state on the planet.

It's not at all wonderful for those of us that actually have to live in Kasich's Ohio.  Notice Cleveland at the top of the list of the have-not cities in the country.  Public education decimated, both K-12 and higher ed, huge number of adults with no jobs.  Young adults are fleeing the state, as they should.  If you want to buy a 4 bedroom house, next to a beautiful park with gardens and lakes designed by Olmstead, for under $50,000 come to Youngstown OH. Have a retirement income or be able to telecommute though.  You won't make money here.

Sorry, Carson made no sense. He sounded more fogged between the ears than usual.

Kasich, however, would have made a great candidate in 2000.

And yet ... look how many Ohio cities are on this map of places the recovery never reached: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/02/24/business/distress-cities-c...®ion=top-stories-below&WT.nav=top-stories-below

You won't see local politicians running for town council acting this rude, immature and unprofessional.

America, this is the best your Republican Party can put forth. I really feel like I need to pinch myself.

And the Democrats offer two aging white people.  One is corrupt and being investigated by the FBI and the other is a socialist offering free stuff.  America, this is the best your two parties can offer.  Time for a third option!

Buckeye1978 - Our tax dollars are supposed to pay for things that benefit all of us, education, health care, infrastructure etc.

Do you really prefer giving "free stuff" to millionaires and billionaires?
At times it felt about as uncomfortable as watching a food fight.  Terribly embarrassing.
GOP a little to late. The bus has left the building.
That's why we support Hillary!  Tonight alone Trump insulted Germany, England, Libya and more.  Great mediator he'd be.

Tweedledee and Tweedledum finally decided to do oppo-research. But it's way too late -- demonstrating their ridiculous passivity for all those months, a passivity that allowed Donald Trump to cement his political brand without any opposition.

It was very telling that Ted Cruz was proud of being abrasive and unwilling to work with others.  He didn't blink when Trump pointed out that not one Senator has endorsed him.  Cruz spoke disdainfully of making both friends and agreements.  He is running on being a thorn in the side of associates.  How does he think a President can accomplish anything?  Does he not realize we are a democracy, rather than dictatorship or his personal theocracy?
Ironically, you could ask the same of Bernie Sanders.
Kind of like Obama, huh?
Brilliantly desperate and clearly not presidential with his little one liners and hissy fits.
ooh... a feisty Marco Rubio....how scary....this does not compute...where is my glass of water...please quick ...cut to commercial break!
Rubio is just not Presidential.
Agree that Kasich was the only candidate with a real command of the issues.   I think he also showed himself to be made of presidential timber.
What was obvious:  whenever Rubio spoke, approving hoots followed, regardless of what he said.  An audience of shills?

The GOP is doing everything it can to stack the deck for Rubio. There was one woman who shrieked every time robot boy Rubio said anything. It's so obvious the audiences of the GOP "debates" are being stacked that it just drives more people to Trump as a form of resistance to the establishment kingmakers and puppeteers.
The Rinse my Prebus set has been stuffing audience for the past two debates the GOP has held.  Anyone who wasn't a shill would have sunk under their seat or headed for the exits.
you betcha, it is the "establishment" choice now.
Brilliant has a strange new definition if Rubio was "brilliant".

So what was all the fuss about (like that Supreme Court case) whether people who used the federal exchange to buy health insurance qualified for subsidies, if Rubio's plan gives refundable tax credits to people who can't afford the policies on their own? And how does his plan provide insurance for people who would be too poor to be provided private health insurance through subsidies -- how is he planning to provide health insurance to the people who were supposed to be covered by the Medicaid expansion under the ACA?

As for the debate as a whole, it was difficult for me to remember that this was a debate for a presidential nomination and not some sort of political talk show, what with all the yelling.
Both brilliant observations.  The rich always think tax credits are so cool -- because they worry about keeping their precious money.  And the debate was like Chris Matthews' show.
I guess they'll get the same health care that people were entitled to from 1609-2010 in the Colonies and States.

And "feisty" is an overestimation of Rubio's performance.  Tonight, "Trump, Polish workers.  Google it" replaced "Let us dispense with this notion that President Obama does not know what he is doing" from a few weeks ago as his overused soundbite.

I agree!

Marco uses too many soundbites.

I support candidates with original lines like, "We will build the middle class like president Obama has done for the past wight years!" - Billary.

While the middle class shrinks.....

I don't really know what is happening to the suicidal Republican party, but I do know that if Trump is elected as their presidential candidate all hell will break lose for them. The GOP is going through a full blown identity crisis and they better get their act together or ---- shut up -- for the next five years bc they are doing so, so, so much damage to their party, but also to the American party in general.

Intelligent, Moderate Republicans are aghast and running in flocks away from the current radical ignorant, arrogant GOP party of stupid.
comments.userLocation: Facebook Drive i@ 1 Hacker Way in Menlo Park

comments.commentBody: I have endured as a Republican for 30 years. If the buffoon with a white nationalist fan base is nominated, I'm out. The Grand Old Party will go the way of the Whigs.

"Intelligent, Moderate Republicans are aghast and running in flocks away from the current radical ignorant, arrogant GOP party of stupid."

Yes we are!!!

So, does "all hell will break lose" and "intelligent" mean that, given Trump is your nominee, and surely he will be, that you would back up your statement by casting a vote for Clinton or Sanders? Or would that be a bridge too far for a "moderate republican" when it comes to preventing damage to the "American party"?

Thank you NYT for publishing on the front page the tag teaming picture of the two Senators.

Trump is the man I fear most (and Kasich to an extent) but the two (dare I say clowns?) US Senators?

Hillary would have them served on toasted rye.

How embarrassing for Texans and Floridians.
